feed.title: Stories by ViveK Panchal on Medium
feed.description: Stories by ViveK Panchal on Medium

items.title: My journey Of Google India Challenge Scholarship
items.author: ViveK Panchal
items.description:
About Me

i am vivek panchal from new Delhi . I have done my graduation in Computer science and engineering from W.C.T.M in 2017.

Past Experience:

In 2017 i got placed through my college in a startup company as intern i learned a little bit about android as that company is startup and they taught me android basics which i already am aware. they teach me very basic stuff which i already know .

hell that was really boring days when i go there and sit to learn things which i already know. instead of treating me as intern i feel like i am siting in a coaching center there so i quit going there and do work from home and send them whatever they told me to do .

In the final year we have to submit the projects and my company didn't give me any project neither they helped me .So i made my own project called the chat bot based on AI powered by IBM watson conversation[now known as Watson Assistant] you can check the link to my repository on Github here

Then due to my family and everyone around me i got a little diverted from my interests And enrolled in a institute for preparing for SSC even though i dont love studying history and blah blah..!!! i felt like my life was being wasted not doing what you love makes you really boring and irritating person as well so i did the SSC preparation but yet in doing so keep doing little stuff of my own.

hope you all heared this Beta govt ki tyaari krle bht scope hai .

During that coaching i learned a little about web-development i got to know about the front end development and little bit of GitHub even though i am not good at it but i learned a lot. i learned about Github pages i made my own Portfolio website there put up my all projects that i made there but i always feel like i am lost . while googling stuff i found about the scholarship program and i filed it ..!!!

7th Feb 2018 :

seems like i got lucky and i got this mail from Udacity India

seriously that was an amazing feeling i didn't knew about Udacity and its free courses that time all i was learning was only through YouTube. !!

then i started learning android from scratch i didn't knew that there soo much things that i have never heard of so i loved the lessons there by doing soo i brush up my skills again and during this amazing learning journey of this scholarship challenge i got to know that doing what you love is all that matter !!! so i decided to follow my heart and do what i love in future.

Scholarship Experiences :

firstly coming to Slack and Udacity forum is soo overwhelming it like a tsunami of messages every time i open it just an amazing community . if i got stuck somewhere i just send a message and vola my query is solved in just few minutes i got answer's !!

during this journey we had a lot of quizzes made by moderators of different channels of slack we had Practical challenges that helped me alot. we had a meetup in Delhi NCR group that is organised by “Rahul mahlotra” moderator of our channel #Delhi_ncr .

This is really an amazing experience meeting soo many developers . There were some scholars who also gave presentation on different topics of Android. First presentation was made by Sudhanshu — on Fragments, Second was from Praneet on Youtube Api’s, Third from Anamika on Android Performance.That was really an amazing meetup learned a lot and we even played Dumb-Charades on Android keywords .

https://medium.com/media/258b1ff473a437ef4eec476f8ad8ac51/href

we had collaborative projects on which i contributed a little bit. during which i learned more about GitHub, how to send pull request how Github help in maintaining versions of file. overall i learned a lot here.

There so much to tell but i guess i have to stop here ,Thanks Everyone in the community -Fellow mates , Moderators -Akshit sir and Udacity India who are managing all of this,i am really lucky to be a part of this amazing community.

Thank you @google and Udacity India for giving us this Great opportunity to connect with likely minded peoples. I have been a part of this community and i am very happy for that. I wish this community will be active even after the scholarship programs end regardless if we got selected or not.

that’s my Experience from starting to end. Thank you so much for reading this. Please clap if you liked this article

My journey Of Google India Challenge Scholarship was originally published in Code Yoga on Medium, where people are continuing the conversation by highlighting and responding to this story.

My journey Of Google India Challenge Scholarship was originally published in Code Yoga on Medium, where people are continuing the conversation by highlighting and responding to this story.

items.title: Building a chatBot using IBM watson conversation service
items.author: ViveK Panchal
items.description:
Watson Assistant (formerly Conversation) combines a number of cognitive techniques to help you build and train a bot — defining intents and entities and crafting dialog to simulate Watson Assistant (formerly Conversation).

Getting started

Before you can start using the Watson Assistant (formerly Conversation) service, log in to IBM Cloud and create a service instance.

  1. Log in to IBM Cloud and navigate to the Watson Assistant (formerly Conversation) service:
  • Don’t have IBM Cloud account? Sign up to create a free trial account.
  • Have a IBM Cloud account? Use this link.
  1. In the Service name field, type a unique name for your new instance of the Watson Assistant (formerly Conversation) service. Check the “Pricing Plans” for data limits for the Watson Assistant (formerly Conversation) service
  2. Click Create. You’ll see details about your new instance in the “Service Details” page.

Creating a Workspace

You use the Watson Assistant (formerly Conversation) tool to create workspaces by either creating a new workspace from scratch, or by importing a workspace from JSON file. You can also duplicate an existing workspace within the same service instance.

  1. If the Service Details page is not already open, click your Watson Assistant (formerly Conversation) service instance on the IBM Cloud console. (When you create a service instance, the Service Details page displays.)
  2. On the “Service Details” page, scroll down to Watson Assistant (formerly Conversation) tooling and click Launch tool.
  3. Click Create to create a new workspace.
  4. Specify the details for the new workspace:
  • Name: A name no more than 64 characters in length. This value is required.
  • Description: A description no more than 128 characters in length.
  • Language: The language of the user input the workspace will be trained to understand. The service supports Brazilian Portuguese, English, French, Italian, and Spanish.

5. Click Create. The new workspace is created and now appears as a tile on the Workspaces page.

Creating an intent

You use the Watson Assistant (formerly Conversation) tool to create intents. The number of intents and examples you can create in a single service instance depends on your Watson Assistant (formerly Conversation) service plan:

Create some intents.

  1. In the Watson Assistant (formerly Conversation) tool, open your workspace and then click the Intents tab.
  2. Click Create new.
  3. In the Intent name field, type a descriptive name for the intent. The intent name can contain letters (in Unicode), numbers, underscores, hyphens, and dots. Intent names cannot contain spaces and must not exceed 128 characters. The following are examples of intent names:
  • #weather_conditions
  • #pay_bill
  • #escalate_to_agent

4. Tip: Don’t include the # character in the intent names when you create them in the Watson Assistant (formerly Conversation) tool.

5. In the User example field, type the text of a user example for the intent. An example can be any string up to 1024 characters in length. The following might be examples for the #pay_bill intent:

  • I need to pay my bill.
  • Pay my account balance
  • make a payment

6. Important: Intent names and example text can be exposed in URLs when an application interacts with the service. Do not include sensitive or personal information in these artifacts.

  1. Press Enter or click + to save the example.
  2. Repeat the same process to add more examples. Provide at least 5 examples for each intent. The more examples you provide, the more accurate your application can be.

3.When you have finished adding examples, click Create to finish creating the intent.

Results

The intent you created is added to the Intents tab, and the system begins to train itself on the new data.

You can click any intent in the list to open it for editing. You can make the following changes:

  • Rename the intent.
  • Delete the intent.
  • Add, edit, or delete examples.
  • Move an example to a different intent.

To move an example, select the example by clicking the check box and then click Move to.

Testing your intents

After you have finished creating new intents, you can test the system to see if it recognizes your intents as you expect.

  1. In the Watson Assistant (formerly Conversation) tool, click the icon.

In the Try it out panel, enter a question or other text string and press Enter to see which intent is recognized. If the wrong intent is recognized, you can improve your model by adding this text as an example to the correct intent.Tip: If you have recently made changes in your workspace, you might see a message indicating that the system is still retraining. If you see this message, wait until training completes before testing:

The response indicates which intent was recognized from your input.

If the system did not recognize the correct intent, you can correct it. To correct the recognized intent, click the displayed intent and then select the correct intent from the list. After your correction is submitted, the system automatically retrains itself to incorporate the new data.

  1. If your intents are not being correctly recognized, consider making the following kinds of changes:
  • Add the unrecognized text as an example to the correct intent.
  • Move existing examples from one intent to another.
  • Consider whether your intents are too similar, and redefine them as appropriate.

Creating an entity

You use the Watson Assistant (formerly Conversation) tool to create entities. The number of entities, entity values, and synonyms you can create in a single service instance depends on your Watson Assistant (formerly Conversation) service plan:

  1. In the Watson Assistant (formerly Conversation) tool, open your workspace and then click the Entities tab.
  2. Click Create new.
  3. In the Add the entity name field, type a descriptive name for the entity.The entity name can contain letters (in Unicode), numbers, underscores, and hyphens. For example:
  • @location
  • @menu_item
  • @product
  1. Tips:
  • Don’t include the @ character in the entity names when you create them in the Watson Assistant (formerly Conversation) tool.
  • Entity names can’t contain spaces or be longer than 64 characters. And entity names can’t begin with the string sys-, which is reserved for system entities.

In the Value field, type the text of a possible value for the intent. An entity value can be any string up to 64 characters in length.Important: Don’t include sensitive or personal information in entity names or values. The names and values can be exposed in URLs in an app.

In the Synonyms field, type any synonyms for the entity value. A synonym can be any string up to 64 characters in length. Press Enter to save each synonym.

  1. Click + and repeat the process to add more entity values.
  2. When you are finished adding values and synonyms, click Create.

Building a Dialog

The dialog component of the Watson Assistant (formerly Conversation) service uses the intents and entities that are identified in the user’s input to gather required information and provide a useful response. Your dialog is represented graphically as a tree; create a branch to process each intent that you define.

Post branching Intents and entities, this is how my Watson Assistant (formerly Conversation) Dialog on IBM Cloud looks like

now you can test your bot at the try out feature and integrate it on web app or and Android/iOS application.

you can check refer this link to how it works and go through that to build your own chatbot go here.

Happy coding.

Building a chatBot using IBM watson conversation service was originally published in Code Yoga on Medium, where people are continuing the conversation by highlighting and responding to this story.
